The Asian Development Bank (ADB) has been the major partner 
of  the  Government  of  Mongolia  in  reforming  the  health  sector 
through  the  Health  Sector  Development  Program  (HSDP).  Over 
the  last  5  years,  the  Government  and  Ministry  of  Health  (MOH) 
have  made  great  progress  in  replacing  the  inefficient  hospital-
based  system,  which  is  biased  toward  curative  care,  with  a 
system  based  on  primary  health  care  (PHC)  and  preventive 
services.  In  particular,  the  concept  of  family  medicine  has  been 
introduced  and  a  network  of  family  group  practices  (FGPs) 
established.  However,  much  remains  to  be  done  to  embed  the 
changes  and  deepen  their  impact;  further  efforts  to  improve  the 
quality of FGPs and rationalize hospital facilities and  overstaffing 
are essential.  

 

ADB  will  continue  its  partnership  with  the  Government  in  helping 
(i)  improve  rural  health  service  delivery,  especially  to  achieve 
Millennium  Development  Goals  at  all  levels  of  the  rural  health 
system ;  (ii)  introduce  changes  in  traditional  popular  views  of 
health  services;  (iii)  strengthen  the  reform  process  and  MOH 
capacity to implement reforms; and (iv) study and test initiatives of 
public sector management and health care financing mechanisms 
to improve sector efficiency, sustainability, and pro-poor focus. 
 
The  goal  of  the  Second  Health  Sector  Development  Project 
(HSDP2)  is  to  improve  the  health  of  the  people,  especially  the 
poor  and  vulnerable,  including  women  and  children,  in  targeted 
rural areas. HSDP2 has two objectives: (i) improve the quality and 
utilization of health services in rural areas, especially for the poor 
and  vulnerable;  and (ii)  build  the  capacity  of  the  health  sector, 
extending  the  reforms  in  sector  efficiency,  effectiveness,  and 
sustainability, and institutional development initiated by the HSDP.

HSDP2  will  benefit  the  whole  population  indirectly  through 
nationwide  components  that  support  health  sector  reform  and 
sector institutional building.  
 
Under the targeted rural health service component, about 400,000 
people  in  five  rural  aimags,  representing  18%  of  the  total 
population,  will  benefit  directly  from  improved  availability  and 
quality  of  rural  health  services.  About  48.5%  of  the  population in 
these  HSDP2  aimags  is  poor,  compared  to  the  national  average 
of 36.0%. The targeted aimags also have endemic diseases and a 
high infant mortality rate, which are composite proxies for poverty 
incidence, indicating that most people in the targeted aimags face 
multiple deprivations.   
 
In the five  targeted  aimags,  HSDP2 will  strengthen public health 
education  and  preventive  works  at  the  bag  (community)  level, 
renovate  and  equip  soum  (district)  health  centers  and  aimag 
hospitals, train  staff at all levels of  the health  system  to improve 
the  quality  of  service  delivery,  and  set  up  performance-based 
incentives  in  provider payments to improve service management  
and    increase    attention    to  the  poor  and  vulnerable,  including 
women  and  children.  HSDP2  will  encourage  greater  participation 
of stakeholders. 
 
HSDP2  will  focus  its  support  on  PHC,  which  is  an  internationally 
proven  best  practice  to  meet  the  needs  of  the  poor  and 
vulnerable, especially women and children. Rural PHC is provided 
by bag  feldshers  (community  nurses),  soum  heath  centers, and 
aimag  hospitals  for  referral  cases.  HSDP2  will  reinforce  bag

More  than  98%  of  rural  PHC  providers  (doctors,  nurses,  and

By  focusing  on  PHC,  HSDP2  will  directly  benefit  women  through

HSDP2 is classified as a core poverty intervention with a focus on 
human development and gender and development.      
 
The  Government  is  active  in  introducing  reforms  and changes in 
public  sector  management  and  health  care  financing  systems. 
However,  if  initiatives  are  not  accompanied  by  a  change  in 
capacity and capability of stakeholders of the health sector and an 
efficient  monitoring  and  evaluation  system,  expected  outcomes 
are not likely. This risk will be minimized in HSDP2 through strong 
capacity-building  support,  provision  of  technical  services,  and 
strengthened monitoring systems.  
 
The changes being introduced in health service delivery require a 
change in attitude of staff and clients and in management. HSDP2 
will invest in a public information campaign to manage perceptions 
of a responsive health system and will strengthen management.  
 
Insufficient funds will hamper PHC reform.  Hospital rationalization 
should  be  accelerated  to  reallocate  funds  to  reform  PHC  and 
FGP.  HSDP2  will  support  hospital rationalization  by  intensifying 
policy dialogue, improving efficiency in hospital management, and 
building MOH capacity to plan and monitor hospital restructuring.

RATIONALE:  SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Initial Reform Achievements 

 
A. 
 
Mongolia has been reforming  its  health  care  system  and  health  financing  mechanisms 
2. 
since the early 1990s. The Asian Development Bank (ADB) through Health Sector Development 
Program (HSDP)2 has been  helping the Government plan and implement sector reforms since 
1997 and has introduced significant and necessary changes in the health system. The aim is to 
replace  an  old  Soviet  model,  dominated  by  an  extensive  network  of  hospitals  that  were 
overstaffed,  emphasized  facility-based  curative  care, and not sustainable  after  transition, with 
one that is more responsive to client needs, based on primary health care (PHC) and preventive 
services, of good quality, and sustainable.  
 
3. 
One of the major accomplishments under the HSDP was the introduction of family group 
practices (FGPs) to provide PHC. FGPs—teams of doctors and nurses—work as private entities 
through  contracts  with  local  administrations.  The  Government  established  237  FGPs  in 
Ulaanbaatar  and  in  all  aimag  centers  nationwide  by  early  2002.  FGPs  receive  capitation 
payment  under  performance-based  contracts  that  incorporate  incentives  for  FGPs  to  see  the 
poor. The FGP system serves the poor and vulnerable better than other types of services3.  
 
Other reforms included the introduction of licensing and accreditation. While licensing of 
4. 
FGPs  has  been  established  and  applied  nationwide,  hospital  accreditation  has  been  applied 
only to a limited extent, reflecting weak reform in the hospital sector. Rationalization of hospitals 
and health personnel has reduced the number of beds and staff by 40% since 1990 (to 7.5 beds 
and 13.4 staff per 1,000 population in 2001). However, these ratios are still much higher than in 
comparable countries, and rationalization should be pursued. A review of the progress of HSDP 
implementation is in Appendix 2.

Poor Rural Health Sector Development. The health system in rural areas is composed 
8. 
of bag feldshers (community nurses), soum health centers, and aimag hospitals. Bag feldshers 
and  soum  health  centers  provide  PHC for  rural  populations,  including  health  education,  and 
basic  health  services,  including  maternal  services.  Aimag  hospitals  (250–350  beds)  provide 
first-referral services. For remote areas, inter-soum hospitals are set up as first-referral hospitals. 
Although  providing PHC  to  outpatients,  soum  health  centers  are  equipped  with  beds  mainly 
because of the centers' vast catchment areas and severe climate conditions.  
 
9. 
Unequal  access  to  quality  health  services, and  the worse  health  status  in  rural  than 
urban areas are serious constraints in the health sector. Health resources are  concentrated in 
urban  areas,  particularly  in  Ulaanbaatar,  while  rural  areas  have  a  shortage  of  physicians  and

supplies.  Reflecting  the  low  population  density  and  low  service  quality,  soum  health  centers 
serve only  2–5  outpatients  a  day  and  5-10  deliveries  a  year.  Mortality  rates  are  consistently 
higher  in  rural  than  urban  areas,  indicating  that  rural  Mongolians  have  not  benefited  equally 
from health service improvement.  
 
10. 
Human  resources  are  scarce  in  rural  areas.  Isolation,  lack  of  opportunity  for  medical 
consultation  with  colleagues,  limited  practice  due  to  the  small  population,  lack  of  up-to-date 
technical  material,  limited  opportunity  for  on-the-job  training  and  continuing  education  with 
appropriate  supervision,  and  difficult  transportation  and  communication  conditions  are  major 
obstacles to attracting and retaining qualified health staff in rural areas. Recently, the Ministry of 
Health  (MOH)  prepared a strategy  to  strengthen  soum  health  centers,  proposing to renovate 
and equip health centers, train and retain soum health workers, and pilot capitation  payment at 
the  soum  level.  HSDP2  will  assist  this  MOH  initiative  and  provide  an  integrated  set  of 
improvements.   
 
Inefficient  Hospital  Management.  Hospital 
11. 
rationalization is still a major challenge. HSDP set an initial target of 7.5 hospital beds per 1,000 
population, which was met in 1999, but is still high for Mongolia’s economic level.  Much of the 
health  budget  is spent keeping  hospitals  open and  heated, depleting funds to finance care  of 
patients. If hospitals are not further rationalized, investment impact will be diluted.   
 
12. 
Rationalization  should  make  hospital  management  more  efficient.  Hospital  care  is 
characterized  by  long  stays  (10.72  days)  and  relatively  high  admission  rates  (20.4%  of  the 
population are hospitalized annually), leading to high bed occupancy. Long stays are driven by 
perverse  funding  arrangements,  low  quality  of  services  caused  by  shortage  of  drugs  and 
outdated treatment protocols, and facility-based protocols for infectious disease control, such as 
for  tuberculosis.  Many  admissions  are  for  pathologies  that  would  be  treated  on  an  outpatient 
basis in international practice, such as headache, hypertension, and diabetes.  Improvement in 
efficiency  of  hospital  management,  including  introduction  of  appropriate  admission  criteria, 
international  standard  treatment  guidelines,  and output based provider  payment mechanisms, 
will reduce the required level of accommodation. The quality of PHC should be improved, and 
demand for it increased to reduce the need and demand for hospitals. 
 
13. 
However, resistance  is strong  to  reducing the number of beds and  hospitals,  not  only 
among  health  personnel  and  MOH  but  also  among  the people,  who  are  accustomed  to  the 
hospital-based  system.  MOH’s  previous  plans  to  close  or  merge  hospitals  have  been 
suspended due to protests from the  people. External  assistance has not been coordinated to 
facilitate rationalization. New hospitals are being built and the number of hospital beds has been 
increasing  in  Ulaanbaatar  since  2000.  Policy  dialogue  with  the  Government  needs  to  be 
renewed to pursue rationalization.   
 
14. 
Poor Human Resources Development. The large-scale changes that have taken place 
in  clinical  and  managerial  arrangements  over  the  past  decade  have  created  many  new 
challenges for staff at all levels of the health system. Overstaffing and staff maldistribution have 
continued  to  hamper  sector  efficiency.  The  number  of  physicians  has  increased  since  1999, 
particularly  in  Ulaanbaatar.  The  current  high  demand  for  physician  training,  and  a  lack  of 
congruency between service needs and training intakes, has led to significant overproduction of 
physicians. Medical university students should be reduced, and incentives given to  physicians 
and nurses to stay in rural and remote areas.  
 

 Decentralization  has  become  a  government  priority.  Provincial  governments  became 
15. 
responsible  for  delivering  and  financing  health  services,  while  MOH  has  shifted  to  policy 
development, strategic planning, regulation and standard setting, and monitoring and evaluation. 
However, local governments lack experience, and planning and managerial capacity in resource 
allocation in the health sector. Some have diverted resources from health care to other sectors. 
Few have been able to  follow  MOH’s broad policy of shifting resources from hospitals to PHC. 
Despite  MOH’s  overall  responsibility  for  workforce  planning,  and  the  recently  developed 
National  Health  Workforce  Plan  2002-2012,  local  governments  continue  to  recruit,  distribute, 
and train staff within the budget framework set by the Ministry of Finance and Economy (MOFE) 
in ways that may not always match MOH’s plan.  If  decentralization is to produce the expected

1. 

Economic Benefits 

 
78. 
Investment  under  HSDP2  is  expected  to  yield  substantial  economic,  social,  and 
institutional  benefits.  The  major  benefits  from  HSDP2  are  out-of-pocket  savings,  and 
productivity gains as more resources are channeled to  rural  health.  HSDP2  will  have  several 
positive  health  and  welfare  impacts  that  can  be  quantified  in  economic  terms.  HSDP2  is 
expected  to  increase  the  number  of  persons  receiving  quality  health  care  and  will  contribute 
directly  to  improve  the  productivity  of  target  beneficiaries.  Even  with  relatively  conservative 
assumptions, HSDP2 yields an economic internal rate of return of 24.4%. The real rate of return 
is likely to be higher as healthy workers are able to work more productively and earn more than 
unhealthy workers. These benefits exclude externalities that accrue to HSDP2.    
 

2. 

Fiscal Impact 

 
79. 
HSDP2 has been designed to minimize recurrent cost implications. The improvement of 
the health service delivery system is intended to reduce wastage, improve the internal efficiency 
of health service delivery, improve energy efficiency of health facilities, thus reducing the cost of 
health  care  for  the  individual  and  society.  The  incremental  recurrent  costs  of  HSDP2  arise 
largely from increased access to quality health care. Although new construction and renovation 
of health facilities are financed by ADB proceeds, local governments must operate and maintain 
the premises to ensure sustainability. HSDP invests in PHC that is internationally proven cost-
effective services that, together with minimized recurrent cost, will increase sustainability.      
 
The financial sustainability analysis evaluates the impact of HSDP2 on the government

TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE FOR SUPPORT FOR HEALTH SECTOR REFORM 

Background And Rationale 

 
A. 
 
1. 
The Ministry of Health (MOH) developed a national health policy in 1997, but it was not 
formally  ratified  by  Parliament.  The  public  health  policy  and  other  national  health  programs, 
including  the  Soum  Health  Development  Program,  have  been  endorsed  and  provide  a 
framework for strategic development of the health sector. However, in view of rapid change in 
the  environment,  MOH  needs  to  review  the  continued  applicability  of  some  programs  and 
develop  policies,  particularly  those  related  to  health  financing  and  government-wide  financial 
reforms, to ensure a comprehensive and coherent health sector strategy.   
 
2. 
The Public Sector Finance Management Law (PSFML) was approved in 2002 and is to 
be  effective  from  2003.  The  Government  expects  to  move  rapidly  from  conventional  input- to 
output-based  budgeting.  Since  PSFML  requires  public  agencies  (including  hospitals)  to  be 
funded based on their outputs or products, the outputs that hospital and health services provide 
need to be defined and their costs estimated. This process will help identify population needs, 
assess  budget  needs  to  address  these  concerns,  and  target  resources  to  areas  with  the 
greatest  need  and  with  the  greatest  inequity  in  health  outcomes.  In  the  health  sector,  PSFML 
would  give  MOH  more  control  over  the  budget  process  and  the  use  of  funds  to  meet  overall 
sector  objectives.  PSFML  shifts  the  responsibility  for  health  care  budget  planning  and 
administration  from  the  Ministry  of  Finance  and  Economy  (MOFE)  in  Ulaanbaatar  and  aimag 
governors’  offices  to  MOH  central  and  aimag  offices.  The  PSFML  will  ensure  appropriate 
allocation  for  health  care  at  the  aimag  level.  The  new  process  can  help  streamline  the  health 
system, leading to rationalized services and better-targeted interventions. 
 
3. 
MOH will have to prepare to administer and monitor reforms, staff will require training in 
management and output-based budgeting, activity and service costs will need estimation based 
on  output/performance,  and  performance  indicators  will  need  to  be  identified.  MOH  lacks  staff 
and  the  skills  mix  to  address  this  challenge.  Staff  should  be  trained  and  deployed    for  these 
functions,  and  the  skills  mix  and  capacity  strengthened,  at  the  central  and  aimag  levels,  to 
ensure  proper  training,  administration,  and  monitoring  of  the  new  financial  and  management 
systems. 
 
4. 
The  role  of  the  Health  Insurance  Fund  (HIF)  in  supporting  public  sector  health 
expenditures  and  complementing  government  budgetary  allocations  is  expected  to  increase 
significantly. In 2002, the sources of health care financing were government budget  (74%), HIF 
(23%),  and  cost  sharing  by  patients  (3%).  Services  covered  under  HIF  include  inpatient    and 
outpatient care, and drugs. HIF was established in 1994 and is administered by the State Social 
Insurance General Office (SSIGO) in the Ministry of Social Welfare and Labor (MSWL). Health 
policy and regulations are developed under MOH direction, but health insurance implementation 
and management are under MSWL’s direction.  The evolving roles and functions of HIF should 
be  made  clear,  and  the  links  between  health  policy  and  health  insurance  implementation 
strengthened. 
 
5. 
HIF  aims  at  universal  coverage  through  a  combination  of  compulsory,  voluntary,  and 
employer-employee contributions. Almost 70% of HIF income is from compulsory employer-paid 
premiums.  Voluntary  contributions  were  abolished  recently  and  those  identified  under  social 
assistance programs are eligible to receive government subsidies. However, the impact of these 
reforms on the vulnerable, underserved, and poor is unclear. Recent evidence suggests that a

coverage,  with  some  groups  more  affected  than  others  either  due  to  adverse  selection  or

Tools  will  have  to  be  developed  and  timely  data  collected  and  analyzed  for  effective  decision

strategies.  For  service  users  and  service  providers,  the  participatory  appraisal  and  planning

10.  Mongolia  made  impressive  gains  in  macroeconomic  adjustment  in  the  early  transition 
years. However, during recent years, average growth rate has dropped and high unemployment 
continued. The growth in national income declined to 1.1% in 1990–2000. Mongolia’s per capita 
gross domestic product (GDP) declined to $390 in 2001. Poverty remains high, and 36% of the 
population lives below the poverty line. 
 
11. 
The declining economy has translated into a weakening public sector resource base for 
health. The transition to a market economy has resulted in a decline in public health expenditure 
as  a  percentage  of  GDP,  from  5.4%  in  1990  to  4.2%  in  2000.  Total  public  sector  health 
expenditure was $39.5 million equivalent or only $17 per capita in 2000. This amounts to about 
4.2%  of  GDP,  or  about  10.5%  of  total  government  expenditures.  In  real  terms,  the  share  and 
amount  for  health  have  declined  in  the  past  decade  but  trends  in  recent  years  have  indicated 
increased  spending  in  the  health  sector.  Despite  this,  the  2003  health  budget  reflects  long 
standing  weaknesses  in  the  health  sector,  including  an  oversized  tertiary  sector,  high  utility 
costs, and inadequate capital investment. The budget also represents changes consistent with 
the  new  sector  strategies,  including  greater  investment  in  rural  health  service,  and  expanding 
role for health insurance and greater involvement of the private sector.  
 
12. 
HSDP2 will address these weaknesses and support the proposed reforms. HSDP2 has 
been designed to minimize recurrent cost implications for the Government. The improvement of

individual and society. The incremental recurrent costs of HSDP2 arise largely from increased

financed through the health insurance fund and have, since 2000, comprised about 9% of public

13. 
The financial sustainability analysis evaluates the impact of HSDP2 on the government 
budget. The total financial cost of HSDP2, inclusive of taxes, duties, contingencies, and interest 
charges, is $17.5 million for around 5 years. The Government’s annual share in HSDP2 costs 
will  average  around  $680,000  equivalent,  or  about  1.1%  of  the  health  sector  average  annual 
budget  of  about  $53.9  million  annually.  The  recurrent  costs  to  be  borne  by  the  Government 
during HSDP2 are estimated to be about $590,000 million per year and include (i) the operating 
expenses  of  the  project  implementation  unit,  and  Directorate  for  Medical  Services;  and  (ii) 
operational,  maintenance,  and  replacement  costs  of  new  and  renovated  health  facilities  and 
equipment  under  HSDP2.  FGPs  under  HSDP2  will  continue  to  be  funded  by  the  Government 
during  and  after  HSDP2  implementation.  The  budgetary  impact  of  the  estimated  annual 
recurrent costs during and after HSDP2 implementation is considered minimal.
